title: Foundations (Pt. 1)
text:
Readings
Come to class having read:



Citation
Article




Burton (1963)
URL


Donoho (2017)
URL


Franklin (2024)
URL




Study Guide
The following questions will help guide your reading and prepare you for class discussions:

Thinking about Burton (1963), evaluate the impact of the ‚Äúquantitative revolution‚Äù on the field of Geography.


How do Burton‚Äôs views on the quantitative revolution differ from the perspectives presented in the more recent sources?
How has the relationship between geography and computing evolved over time?
Was the quantitative revolution a singular event or part of a more continuous process?


Thinking about Donoho (2017)‚Äôs definition of data science‚Ä¶


What is the ‚ÄúBig Data‚Äù meme and why does Donoho find it misleading?
Explain Breiman‚Äôs concept of the ‚Äútwo cultures‚Äù in data analysis.
What does Tukey argue are the three essential constituents of a science, and how does he apply them to the field of data analysis?
What are CTFs and how do they relate to the ‚Äúpredictive culture‚Äù of data analysis?
What are the six divisions of the Greater Data Science (GDS) framework?


According to Franklin (2024)‚Ä¶


What are three recent developments that distinguish the current landscape of open software in quantitative methods from previous eras?
What are some of the emerging subfields within quantitative methods, and what common goal do they share?
The author argues that the rebranding of quantitative methods as ‚Äúdata science‚Äù or ‚Äúanalytics‚Äù can be beneficial in certain contexts. Explain these benefits.
What concerns are raised about the fragmentation of the quantitative methods community identity? 







Connections



Franklin (2024) offers another perspective on ‚Äòthe discipline‚Äô of quantitative human geography and its heterogeneity, while Donoho (2017) will give you context on how data science might differ from what‚Äôs covered in Quantitative Methods. You might also find Unwin (1980) useful for understanding why the practicals are set up the way they are and why we don‚Äôt post ‚Äòanswers‚Äô until a few days after the last practical group has completed its session. You should read Burton (1963) while reflecting on Arribas-Bel and Reades (2018) with a view to seeing that ‚Äòthere is nothing new under the sun‚Äô: we tend to think that the challenges we face now in terms of data volumes and complexity are novel, but they are not. Indeed, here‚Äôs John Graham-Cumming keynoting a 2012 conference talking about the Lyons Tea Company and how its programmers invented Dykstra‚Äôs shortest path algorithm more than 20 years before Dykstra did!

title: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle
text:
This week we will look at how frequently-used code can be packaged up in functions and libraries. This is the point at which we begin to engage with code in a more abstract way because we are increasingly interested in reusability and flexibility.






Learning Objectives




To develop an understanding of code re-use through functions.
To develop an appreciation of the utility of packages and namespaces.



This week we also start to move beyond Code Camp, so although you should recognise many of the parts that we discuss, you‚Äôll see that we begin to put them together in a new way. The next two weeks are a critical transition between content that you might have seen before in Code Camp (see Practical) or other introductory materials, and the ‚Äòdata science‚Äô approach.

title: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle
text:
Readings
Come to class prepared to discuss the following readings:



Citation
Article




Massey (1996)
URL


D‚ÄôIgnazio and Klein (2020) Ch.3
URL




Study Guide

Reading Massey‚Äôs seminal ‚ÄúPoliticising space and place‚Äù:


What are the two conflicting geographical imaginations at play in contemporary society? Explain their contradictory nature.
In the case study of ‚Äòhigh-tech‚Äô scientists, how do the ‚Äòpower geometries‚Äô of work and home reflect gendered power relations?


Looking at D‚ÄôIgnazio and Klein‚Äôs ‚ÄúOn Rational, Scientific, Objective Viewpoints from Mythical, Imaginary, Impossible Standpoints‚Äù:


What does the ‚Äúview from nowhere‚Äù concept mean in the context of data visualization, and why do they find it problematic?
How do they propose to address the limitations of data visualization? Describe their concept of ‚Äúdata visceralization‚Äù and its significance.
Why do they suggest that you shouldn‚Äôt never use the ‚Äògod trick‚Äô?







Connections



These are two of the more challenging readings this term, but they are critical to understanding what we are trying to teach you: it‚Äôs not just about learning to code, it‚Äôs about learning how to deploy code/quantitative methods to support your argument, while maintaining a keen eye on how bias ‚Äì in both the technical and the ethical senses ‚Äì can creep into your thinking and, consequently, your results!

title: Numeric Data
text:
This week we will be introducing the use of the pandas library for data analysis and management through a focus on numeric data and its distribution(s). This marks a major shift from working with concepts (lists, dictionaries, functions, etc.) largely in isolation to encountering all of them together ‚Äòin the wild‚Äô as part of a full data science workflow. So we are moving from the acquisition of concepts to their integration in the same way that we will ‚Äî over the course of these three sessions ‚Äî be coming from data acquisition to data integration.






Learning Objectives




An appreciation of how and why this module differs from (QM) CASA0007.
The beginnings of a more integrative understanding of foundational computer science concepts and the practice(s) of data science.
A basic understanding of data acquisition and manipulation in Python.

title: Numeric Data
text:
Readings
Come to class prepared to discuss the following readings:



Citation
Article




Anderson (2008)
URL


D‚ÄôIgnazio and Klein (2020a) Ch.4
URL


Cox and Slee (2016)
URL




Study Guide
Looking at Anderson (2008):

How does the idea of ‚Äúmore is different‚Äù relate to the concept of the Petabyte Age?
What does Anderson mean by ‚ÄúCorrelation is enough‚Äù?
What examples does Anderson provide to show that the scientific method is becoming obsolete?

Reading D‚ÄôIgnazio and Klein (2020a, Ch.4):

How do their ideas about the power dynamics of data collection challenge Anderson‚Äôs claim that ‚Äúthe numbers speak for themselves‚Äù?
What are the potential consequences of relying solely on correlation, as Anderson suggests, without considering the social and political contexts of data?
How might the concept of the ‚Äúprivilege hazard‚Äù inform an analysis of Anderson‚Äôs argument?

Considering Cox and Slee (2016):

How does the case study presented in Cox and Slee illustrate the issues explored in the other readings?
According to Cox and Slee, how did the cleaning of the New York City listings reflect the company‚Äôs power and privilege?
How does this cleaning potentially harm less-privileged stakeholders in the company‚Äôs platform?







Connections



Read D‚ÄôIgnazio and Klein (2020b) to highlight the importance of thinking about what a data set captures‚Ä¶ and what it excludes. Cox and Slee (2016) is also a first introduction to the underlying data that we‚Äôll be working with over the rest of term. D‚ÄôIgnazio and Klein (2020b) should be getting you thinking about how ‚Äòcleaning‚Äô is not just about hygiene but has real implications for what you can and will find in your data: data is often a lot less ‚Äòtidy‚Äô than tidyr might lead you think! You should almost never be claiming that your (social) data represents the ‚Äòuniverse‚Äô of behaviours or is somehow ‚Äòcomplete‚Äô.

It is hoped that you will see how Pandas combines and builds on techniques that we‚Äôve already seen: while Pandas is incredibly sophisticated, the underlying concepts have been covered in the preceding three weeks! At this point we will also begin to make use of Pandas functionality to subset and explore the data.






Connections

Seeing how Pandas is ‚Äòjust‚Äô a sophisticated extension of what we‚Äôve already done.

Performing basic data cleaning and exploration tasks (including visualisation).

title: Textual Data
text:
Although the direct use of textual (both structured and unstructured) data is still relatively rare in spatial analyses, the growth of crowd-sourced and user-generated content points to the growing importance of this area. he tools and approaches in this area are also evolving quickly and changing rapidly, so this week is intended primarily to familiarise you with the basic landscape in preparation for you developing your skills further in your own time!






Learning Outcomes




An awareness of the benefits of separating content from presentation.
A basic understanding of pattern-matching in Python (you will have been exposed to this Week 2 of CASA0005)
A basic understanding of how text can be ‚Äòcleaned‚Äô to make it more amenable for analysis
An appreciation of parallelisation in the context of text processing.
An appreciation of how text can be analysed.




The manipulation of text requires a high level of abstraction ‚Äì of thinking about words as data in ways that are deeply counter-intuitive ‚Äì but the ability to do forms a critical bridge between this block and the subsequent one, while also reinforcing the idea that numerical, spatial, and textual data analyses provide alternative (and often complementary) views into the data.

title: Textual Data
text:
Readings
Come to class prepared to discuss the following readings:



Citation
Article




Miller and Goodchild (2015)
URL


Delmelle and Nilsson (2021)
URL


Reades et al. (2025)
URL




Study Guide
Reading Miller and Goodchild (2015):

How does ‚Äúdata-driven geography‚Äù differ from traditional geographic research?
How can ‚Äúdata-driven approaches‚Äù be incorporated into geographic research, and what are their potential benefits and limitations?

Reflecting on Reades et al. (2025):

Why has text become increasingly interesting to computational social scientists?
What are the specific advantages of textual data for understanding cities?
What are some of the key challenges and limitations of using textual data in urban research, and how can researchers address these challenges?

Connecting this to Delmelle and Nilsson (2021):

What is the framework that Delmelle and Nilsson developed for understanding the language used to advertise properties, and how does it connect to the racial and income profiles of neighborhoods?
What are the implications for understanding neighborhood change and (potential) discrimination in the housing market?

Collecitvely:

How do these readings connect to the broader themes of the course, and what are the implications for your own research?







Connections



Conceptually, this is by far the hardest week of the entire term: there is very little upon which to draw from other modules, and the processing of text with computers rarely makes it beyond simple regular expressions; however, the growth in data that is ‚Äòaccidental, open, and everywhere‚Äô (Arribas-Bel 2014) means that a lot more of it is unstructured and contains free-text written by humans as well as numerical and coordinate data generated by sensors or transactions.


If you‚Äôre feeling ambitious then you can use the tutorial from the Programming Historian to look at the foundations of text processing and how we can extract important terms from a document as well as, ultimately, the foundations upon which modern Large Language Models are built.

title: Getting Help
text: We all need help from time to time, and while we will always do our best to support you because we know that this module is hard for students who are new to programming, the best way to ‚Äòget help‚Äô will also always be taking steps to ‚Äòhelp yourself‚Äô first.

title: Getting Help
text:
How to Help Yourself
Here are at least six things that you can do to ‚Äòhelp yourself‚Äô:

Use the dedicated #fsds channel on Slack‚Äìthis provides a much richer experience than the Moodle Forum and should be your primary means of requesting help outside of scheduled teaching hours.
Do the readings‚Äìregardless of whether we ask you questions in class about them (or not), the readings are designed to support the module‚Äôs learning outcomes, so if you are struggling with a concept or an idea then please look to the week‚Äôs readings! You should also review the full bibliography while developing your thinking for the final project.
Use Google‚Äìthis is one course where saying ‚ÄúI googled it‚Ä¶‚Äù will be taken as a good sign! Probalby the biggest difference between a good programmer and a new programmer is that the good one knows which terms to type into Google to get the answer that they need right away.
Use Stack Overflow‚Äìas you become a better programmer you‚Äôll start to understand how to frame your question in ways that produce the right answer right away, but whether you‚Äôre a beginner or an expert Stack Overflow is your friend.
Make use of Drop-in Hours (see also below)‚Äìthere is no extra credit for struggling in silence, and we can‚Äôt help you if we don‚Äôt know that you‚Äôre lost! That doesn‚Äôt mean that we can simply ‚Äògive‚Äô you the answers to challenging questions, but we will do everything that we can to support your learning. Many of the same advice applies here as on our other Getting Help page (with the Soft Skills).
Practice like it‚Äôs a language‚Äìset yourself little problems or tasks and see if you can apply what you‚Äôve learned in class to a problem in a different class, or a friend‚Äôs problem, or just something you‚Äôre curious about! In the same way that practicing your Chinese or French with native speakers will help you to learn those languages, so will practicing your Python.
Sign up for online classes‚Äìrealistically, you will have a lot on your plate, but if you want or need more practice with Python and are strugging to come up with your own problems to work through then there is a wealth of options out there. You might also find that a different explanation or challenge resonates and gives you new insight into how to code.

Remember: when you are learning to code there is no such thing as a stupid question. Sometimes students have lazy questions when they are frustrated and just want to know ‚Äòthe answer‚Äô, but anyone finding themselves stuck on a particular problem has a 100% chance that someone else in the class has the same problem as well but hasn‚Äôt quite worked up the courage to ask. So please: ask.

Dani for help with Docker, geopandas, and any number of other new tools with which I‚Äôve had to familiarise myself.

The Geocomp team at King‚Äôs College London, who supported my hare-brained scheme to teach Geography undergrads to code and offered all manner of useful feedback on what we could/could not feasibly cover.
